Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Models, analytics, and algorithms for data driven applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Data driven applications are becoming increasingly prevalent as our ability to collect data continue to increase and the cost continues to decrease. Examples of such applications include social networks (twitter, facebook, etc.), bioinformatics (gene regulatory networks, genomic sequence analysis), and environmental monitoring using wireless sensor networks. As more data
become available, how to convert data to actionable information to guide decision is a pending problem that will have many applications. In addition to being "big", the data and underlying phenomena also exhibit time-variations which add to the
difficulty of gleaning useful information from data. To cope with these challenges, this project will develop an flexible algorithmic framework using Dynamic Bayesian Networks, which can sufficiently describe the physical reality, and at the
same time are expressive enough to allow for machine based learning, optimization, inference and adaptation to dynamical
data. Such a computational framework can assimilate data continuously, adaptively, and reduce the data to information in
a format that is logical, intuitive, and amenable to human interactions.Such features are particularly needed for large-scale,
data-intensive engineering systems and networks such as structural health monitoring, surveillance and disease discovery
using gene regulatory networks.


Intellectual Merit:

The proposed project will build on existing work on graphical models and explore the largely open area of learning dynamical graphical models based on measured data. Algorithms will be developed based on convex optimization formulation for online
adaptation of the graphical models. Partially known structural information, and issues with noisy, incomplete, corrupted,
or missing data will be examined. The proposed research will advance the status of the art of learning from dynamical data,
and explore the many under-explored connections between signal processing, and information theory, statistics,
and machine learning.

Broader Impact: The proposed research will develop generic models and analytical tools for data based applications.
It will also generate low-complexity algorithms that can be adapted to a large number of applications such as
wireless sensor networks, gene-regulatory networks, and genomic sequence analysis. The research will allow data
that are made available through digital technologies to be converted to information automatically by computers,
which can then be understood and acted upon by humans. The educationalgoal of this proposed project is to efficientl
integrate research with educational activities and to train both undergraduate and graduate students in interdisciplinary
areas to produce next-generation engineers. Efforts will be made to invite women, underpresented, and minority undergraduate
students to participate in the proposed research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project aimed to develop models, analytics, and algorithms that are applicable to data-driven applications. These applications are becoming increasingly important as we collect more data and develop more computing power to process the data. Examples of such applications include social networks (twitter, facebook, etc.), bioinformatics (gene regulatory networks, genomic sequence analysis), and environmental monitoring using wireless sensor networks. Many of such data-driven applications involve learning patterns from data and they require optimization algorithms that can solve the large-scale problems efficiently and with high quality.

The proposed research has advanced the status of the art of learning from data and explored the connections between signal processing, and information theory, statistics, and machine learning. We have developed theoretical models and practical algorithms for data-driven problems and machine learning from data. Many problems in data analytics involve matrix factorization. We studied an important type of factorization, namely nonnegative matrix factorization, which is a hard problem because of the nonconvexity nature of the problem. We developed efficient algorithms for the problem and provided theoretical guarantees on the convergence speed of them. A stochastic version of the algorithms was also developed that can deal with time-varying data and models. We have developed efficient optimization algorithms that can be proven to be able to escape from "bad" points. We also obtain theoretical results as to how fast such algorithms converge to their final solutions. We developed algorithms that rely on a set of randomly generated classifiers, followed by a selection process based on the performance of these classifiers on the whole set of training data. We developed algorithms for covariance estimation for large-dimensional data when certain data points are missing.

In terms of applications, we have looked at the gene regulatory network inference problem, and we studied the interesting (and more difficult case) where the inference is based on dynamic gene expression data. Graphical model and nonlinear differential equation based models were developed and efficient algorithms were developed for the problem with competitive results. We also modeled and developed algorithms for detecting copy number variations based on sequencing data of sample and control species.

The project integrated research with educational activities and trained students in interdisciplinary areas to produce next-generation engineers. The developed models, analytic methods, and algorithms advanced not only the research field of machine learning and data analytics but also will be useful and have the positive impact in other disciplines where data-driven methods play increasingly important roles.
